Enumerator Documentation¶

Contents:

Utilities¶

class utils.Complex(name, strands, structure)[source]¶

Bases: object

Represents a complex, which is a set of connected strands with a particular secondary structure.

__eq__(other)[source]¶

Tests two complexes for equality. Complexes are equal if and only if they have the same strands (in the same order) and the same structure. This works because of the uniqueness of nonpseudoknotted representations of nonpseudoknotted structures (assuming everything is in canonical form and strands have unique names).

__init__(name, strands, structure)[source]¶

Constructor for complex objects. Takes a name, the ordered list of strands, and the appropriate structure. Complexes are assumed to be nonpseudoknotted, and the strand list should be in the order that yields a nonpseudoknotted structure.

A complex is in ‘canonical form’ if its strands are in a non-pseudoknotted circular permutation with the strand with the minimum name lexicographically as the first in the list of strands.

This constructor assumes that the structure is unpseudoknotted, and will rotate this complex automatically until it is in canonical form.

Parameters:
  • name – string holding complex name
  • strands – list of Strand objects in order
  • structure –

    list of lists of tuples indicating pairing of domains in the complex. None indicates the domain is unpaired, while a (strand, domain) tuple indicates the domain is paired to domain on strand.

    Examples:

    • [[(0, 2) None (0, 0)]] indicates one strand with 3 domains with the first one bound to the last one, and the middle one free.
    • [[None (1, 0) (1, 1)], [(0, 1) (0, 2) None]] indicates 2 strands with 3 domains each – the first two domains of the second strand are bound to the last two of the first.

    Lists should be in the same order as the strands in the second argument, with each strand’s domains from 5’ to 3’
__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

check_structure()[source]¶

Determines whether the structure includes pairs only between complementary domains. Returns True if all paired domains are complementary, raises an Exception otherwise

clone()[source]¶

Returns a deep copy of this complex.

dot_paren_string()[source]¶

Returns the segment-wise dot paren representation of this complex.

dot_paren_string_full()[source]¶

Returns the base-wise dot paren representation of this complex.

get_domain(loc)[source]¶

Returns the domain at the given (strand,domain) index in this complex (loc is a (strand,domain) tuple)

rotate_strands()[source]¶

Returns a deep copy of this complex with its strands rotated once.

strand_index(strand_name)[source]¶

Returns the index of the strand with the specified name in this complex, or -1 if there is no such strand.

update_available_domains()[source]¶

Updates the internal list of available domains. Any domains on an external loop are added to this list. Sets _valid_available_domains to true on completion.

class utils.Domain(name, length, is_complement=False, sequence=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Represents a single domain. We allow several options for specifying domain properties. Domains might have an explicit integer (bp) length, or may be designated as short or long. If the latter method is used, the code will use the relevant constant as the integer domain length.

__init__(name, length, is_complement=False, sequence=None)[source]¶

Default constructor. Takes a domain name, a length (positive integer or “short” or “long”), and optionally a base sequence.

__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

can_pair(other)[source]¶

Returns True if this domain is complementary to the argument.

identity[source]¶

Returns the identity of this domain, which is its name without a complement specifier (i.e. A and A* both have identity A).

is_complement[source]¶

Returns true if this domain is a complement or not.

length[source]¶

The length of this domain. Either uses the integer length previously specified or the constant associated with “short” and “long” domains as appropriate.

name[source]¶

The name of this domain.

sequence[source]¶

This domain’s sequence. May be None if no sequence was specified.

class utils.RestingState(name, complexes)[source]¶

Bases: object

Represents a resting state, which is a collection of complexes.

__init__(name, complexes)[source]¶

Constructor for RestingState objects. Takes a (unique) name and list of complexes.

__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

class utils.Strand(name, domains)[source]¶

Bases: object

Represents a strand, which is an ordered sequence of domains.

__init__(name, domains)[source]¶

Constructor for Strand objects. Takes a strand name and the ordered list of Domain objects from 5’ to 3’.

__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

utils.find(f, seq, default=None)[source]¶

Return first item in sequence where f(item) == True.

utils.natural_sort(l)[source]¶

Sorts a collection in the order humans would expect. Implementation from http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4836710/does-python-have-a-built-in-function-for-string-natural-sort

Reactions¶

class reactions.ReactionPathway(name, reactants, products)[source]¶

Bases: object

Represents a reaction node on a reaction graph. Has a list of reactants and a list of products, along with a name field to denote the type of reaction involved.

__init__(name, reactants, products)[source]¶

Default constructor. Takes a name, a list of reactants (Complexes) and a list of products (Complexes).

__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

normalize()[source]¶

Ensures that complexes appear on only one side of the reaction by removing them evenly from both sides until only one side has any.

reactions.bind11(reactant)[source]¶

Returns a list of reaction pathways which can be produced by 1-1 binding reactions of the argument complex. The 1-1 binding reaction is the hybridization of two complementary unpaired domains within a single complex to produce a single unpseudoknotted product complex.

reactions.bind21(reactant1, reactant2)[source]¶

Returns a list of reaction pathways which can be produced by 2-1 binding reactions of the argument complexes. The 2-1 binding reaction is the hybridization of two complementary unpaired domains, each in a different complex, to produce a single, unpseudoknotted product complex containing all of the strands contained in either of the original complexes.

reactions.branch_3way(reactant)[source]¶

Returns a list of reaction pathways that can be created through one iteration of a 3 way branch migration reaction (more than one molecule may be produced by a reaction because branch migration can liberate strands and complexes).

reactions.branch_4way(reactant)[source]¶

Returns a list of complex sets that can be created through one iteration of a 4 way branch migration reaction (each set consists of the molecules that result from the iteration; more than one molecule may result because branch migration can liberate strands and complexes).

reactions.combine_complexes_21(complex1, location1, complex2, location2)[source]¶

Combines two complexes to form one complex, binding the domain in complex1 at location1 to the domain in complex2 at location2.

Returns the new complex.

reactions.do_3way_migration(reactant, displacing_loc, new_bound_loc)[source]¶

Returns the product set which is the result of a 3-way branch migration reaction where the domain at displacing_loc displaces the domain bound to the domain at new_bound_loc.

reactions.do_4way_migration(reactant, loc1, loc2, loc3, loc4)[source]¶

Performs a 4 way branch migration on a copy of reactant, with loc1 as the displacing domain, loc2 as the domain displaced from loc1, loc3 as the template domain, and loc4 as the domain displaced from loc3. Returns the set of complexes produced by this reaction (may be one or more complexes).

reactions.find_external_strand_break(complex, location)[source]¶

Takes a complex and a location (strand+domain index) referring to a domain in the complex which is on an external loop. Returns the index of the last strand before the strand break which makes the argument domain on an external loop.

The argument location is a tuple (strand_num, index_num)

# TODO: This is really confusingly worded...

reactions.find_releases(reactant)[source]¶

Determines if reactant actually represents multiple unattached complexes. If so, returns a list of these complexes. Otherwise, returns [reactant].

reactions.open(reactant)[source]¶

Returns a list of reaction product sets that can be produced by the ‘open’ reaction, in which a short helix dissociates. Each product set are the results of one particular dissociation; each strand in the reactant occurs exactly once in one of the complexes in the product set.

A dissociation can happen to any helix under the threshold length

reactions.split_complex(reactant, split_start, split_end)[source]¶

Splits a disconnected complex between split_start and split_end (which should be at ends of strands), and returns the two resulting complexes.

Enumerator¶

class enumerator.Enumerator(domains, strands, initial_complexes)[source]¶

Bases: object

Represents a single enumerator instance, consisting of all the information required for a reaction graph. This class is the coordinator for the state enumerator. Enumerators have immutable starting conditions. If unzip is true, all 3-way branch migrations are greedy.

__init__(domains, strands, initial_complexes)[source]¶

Initializes the enumerator. Takes a list of domains, a list of strands made up of those domains, and a list of the initial complexes, made of the strands.

Parameters:
  • domains (list) – Domain objects in the ensemble
  • strands (list) – Strand objects in the ensemble
  • initial_complexes (list) – Complex objects in the system starting configuration.
__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

complexes[source]¶

” List of complexes enumerated. enumerate() must be called before access.

enumerate()[source]¶

Generates the reaction graph consisting of all complexes reachable from the initial set of complexes. Produces a full list of complexes(), resting states, and :py:meth:`reactions, which are stored in the associated members of this class.

get_fast_reactions(complex)[source]¶

Returns a list of fast reactions possible using complex as a reagent.

get_new_products(reactions)[source]¶

Checks the products in the list of reactions. Updates the pointers in those reactions to point to pre-existing complexes if necessary. Else, returns the new complexes in a list.

Additionally, prunes passed reactions to remove those with excessively large complexes (len(complex) > self.MAX_COMPLEX_SIZE)

get_slow_reactions(complex)[source]¶

Returns a list of slow reactions possible using complex and other complexes in list E as reagents.

This only supports unimolecular and bimolecular reactions. Could be extended to support arbitrary reactions.

initial_complexes[source]¶

Complexes present in the system’s initial configuration

process_neighborhood(source)[source]¶

Takes a single complex, generates the ‘neighborhood’ of complexes reachable from that complex through fast reactions, classifies these complexes as transient or resting state, and modifies the lists and list of reactions accordingly.

reactions[source]¶

” List of reactions enumerated. enumerate() must be called before access.

resting_complexes[source]¶

” List of complexes enumerated that are within resting states. enumerate() must be called before access.

resting_states[source]¶

” List of resting states enumerated. enumerate() must be called before access.

segment_neighborhood(complexes, reactions)[source]¶

Segments a set of complexes and reactions between them representing a neighborhood into resting states and transient states. Returns the set of complexes which are transient states, complexes which are in resting states, and the set of resting states, all in a dictionary.

Parameters:
  • complexes – set of complexes
  • reactions – set of reactions
Returns:

dictionary with keys:

  • resting_states: set of resting states
  • resting_state_complexes: set of resting state complexes
  • transient_state_complexes: set of transient complexes
tarjans(node)[source]¶

Executes an iteration of Tarjan’s algorithm (a modified DFS) starting at the given node.

transient_complexes[source]¶

” List of complexes enumerated that are not within resting states (e.g. complexes which are transient). enumerate() must be called before access.

enumerator.fast_reactions = {1: [<function bind11 at 0x1020ebb90>, <function open at 0x1020d6ed8>, <function branch_3way at 0x102c070c8>, <function branch_4way at 0x102c071b8>]}¶

Dictionary of reaction functions considered fast for a given “arity”. Keys are arities (e.g. 1 = unimolecular, 2 = bimolecular, 3 = trimolecular, etc.), and values are lists of reaction functions. Currently, only unimolecular fast reactions (arity = 1) are supported.

enumerator.slow_reactions = {1: [], 2: [<function bind21 at 0x1020d6d70>]}¶

Similar to fast_reactions() above, a dictionary of reaction functions considered slow for a given “arity”. Keys are arities (e.g. 1 = unimolecular, 2 = bimolecular, 3 = trimolecular, etc.), and values are lists of reaction functions. Currently, only unimolecular fast reactions (arity = 1) are supported. Slow reactions can only be unimolecular or bimolecular, though Enumerator.make_slow_reactions() below could be changed in order to lift this restriction.

Input and Output¶

output.output_condensed_graph(enumerator, filename)[source]¶

Products graphical output representing the condensed reaction graph, with condensed reactions and resting states aggregated into single nodes.

output.output_full_graph(enumerator, filename)[source]¶

Products graphical output representing the full reaction graph, with all reactions and complexes. Transient and resting states are differentiated by color.

output.output_json(enumerator, filename, output_condensed=False)[source]¶

JSON-based output schema intended to be easily machine parsable. Uses python’s JSON serialization libraries.

output.output_legacy(enumerator, filename, output_condensed=False)[source]¶

Legacy text-based output scheme similar to that used in the original enumerator. Designed to be simultaneously parsable and human-readable. Supports output of condensed graph in addition to the full graph. Does not support strands.

output.output_pil(enumerator, filename, output_condensed=False)[source]¶

Text-based output using the Pepper Intermediate Language (PIL)

input.input_pil(filename)[source]¶

Initializes and returns an enumerator from an input file in the Pepper Intermediate Language (PIL)

input.input_standard(filename)[source]¶

Initializes and returns an enumerator from a standard input file.

input.load_json(filename)[source]¶

Loads a saved enumerator from a JSON output file at filename.
